newsitem.title: DUBAI: Dubai gold trade reports brisk end to retail blitz.
newsitem.headline: Dubai gold trade reports brisk end to retail blitz.

text.p: Dubai gold traders said business in the week to Sunday was buoyant, thanks to frantic retail jewellery sales at the end of a month- long shopping promotion.
But the price of investment bars and coins in the local market stayed under pressure, trading in narrow ranges in line with international bullion, they said.
"This week demand was brilliant. Everyone was rushing to buy gold jewellery so they could enter the 10 kg (22 lbs) raffle draw," a trader at a large Dubai jewellery manufacturer said.
"Sales were extremely good, and I would say even better than last year's shopping festival. But now that it is over, we should see things slow down," said another.

During the promotion, which ended on Saturday, customers spending over 500 dirhams ($136) on gold at the downtown souk could enter a daily draw for one kg (2.2 lbs) of the precious metal and an end-of-festival 10 kg prize.
Traders estimated this generated between seven and 10 tonnes more business in the month.
They quoted the Dubai benchmark ten tola bar -- 3.746 ounces of 24 carat gold -- at 4,730 dirhams ($1,289) on Sunday from 4,720-4,725 dirhams a week earlier.
On the international market, spot gold was last quoted on Saturday at $342.20/70 an ounce from the previous week's $341.20/90.
Dealers said demand from India in the week had continued on an even keel after a bout of political upheaval earlier in the month, coupled with lower world prices, prompted more buying.
After New Delhi's 10-month-old minority government was defeated in a parliamentary confidence vote on April 11, a new prime minister, Inder Kumar Gujral, was sworn in last Monday.

While traders said local retail sales would no doubt fall with the end of the shopping promotion, they forecast a further pick up in demand from India as the country's second wedding season gets into full swing.

Indian and Pakistani buyers are also expected to continue to take advantage of weak global prices -- which in recent weeks tested the four-year lows seen in January -- to stock up on gold bars and coins from Dubai. ($1=3.67 dirhams)
